I'm not religious; I'm somewhat hostile to religion, in general. I prefer science. Unitarianism, bland & unformed as it is, was still too much like a religion for me. Quit that long ago. But I grew up Catholic & am Jesuit-educated, so I'm Christ-infected. Merry Christmas! 8/8

Ever since then I've looked at Christmas differently. On Christmas we mark the arrival of one incarnation of the Christ, a miraculous thing well worth noting & celebrating. But it reminds me that the Incarnation happens all over the world, thousands of times, every day. 7/8.

From there followed some implications, some obvious, some not so much. It may be that everything he said that morning was just sentimental pap, but it didn't strike me that way. I found it very moving & thought-provoking. (Ferris knew his way around the Gospels, btw). 6/n

And from there he built an essay on the idea that every child is the Christ child; every infant is divine, he himself had once been the Christ child, as had every adult listening to him. But we had grown out of Christhood, as nature ordains. 5/n

But then he said that the Christ Child was also with us that very day, in that very room, and called our attention to an infant in their mother's arms in one of the pews. "Behold the Christ," he said. 4/n

Most Unitarians don't consider themselves Christian, and many are atheists, pagan, or pretty much areligious. So when early in his remarks the minister Ferris said that he believed the infant Jesus born to Mary in Bethlehem was, in fact, the Christ, it caught my attention. 3/n
This synopsis is from a very fallible memory of a sermon I heard at least 30 years ago. Take it for what it's worth. 2/n
